forecast.review: Both forecasters largely mirror my base case: FPTP conversion, zero incumbency, weak local infrastructure, and historical base rates make Reform becoming the largest party extraordinarily unlikely. Forecaster 2’s 3% rests on tail-risk from national polling around mid-20s and the possibility of concentrated support; that’s a reasonable consideration but still feels generous absent local evidence. Forecaster 3’s emphasis on the unprecedented nature and short time horizon is persuasive, though their claim that Reform would need “at least 33” seats to be the largest is not strictly necessary—plurality could be achieved with fewer if the field fragments heavily. That correction doesn’t change the bottom line: getting to even 20+ seats from a standing start remains implausible. Neither added concrete local indicators (division-level polling, canvass returns, by-election analogs) that would justify moving off a very low base.
forecast.rationale: I remain anchored to structural and base-rate arguments: (1) Reform starts with zero councillors and no incumbency; (2) FPTP severely penalizes diffuse support; (3) local election success hinges on organization and candidate quality, both weak spots for Reform; (4) insurgent right parties (UKIP/Brexit) historically failed to top county councils even at higher-momentum moments; (5) no credible Derbyshire-specific data show Reform leading in a meaningful number of divisions. Even if national support is 23–25% and somewhat concentrated, the plausible ceiling looks like a handful of seats, not the 20–30 required to be largest amid Labour’s likely resurgence and a Conservative slump. The 10-day window with no sign of local polling breakthroughs or major defections further lowers the odds of a late, coordinated surge. I correct Forecaster 3’s ‘33 seats’ point but it doesn’t materially help Reform’s chances; the fragmentation needed for a lower plurality threshold is itself implausible in this context. Net: tail risk exists, but remains very small. No update warranted.
